   Assessment and Plan
 PNEUMONIA, BACTERIAL, COMMUNITY ACQUIRED (CAP)
   1. Sepsis: Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, temperature of >104,
   tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. Likely source is
   pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1, however following fluid
   administration is 1.9. Pt received Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin
   in the ED. Will initiate Zosyn IV and continue Levofloxacin for double
   strep/staph coverage. Will continue Vanc as pt has h.o. of MRSA. As
   below, transiently required pressor support with Levophed.
   --> Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin
   --> Sputum cx, bld cx, urine legionella pending, resent once on floor
   --> Maintain CVP 8-12
   --> Maintain MAP > 65
   --> Continue to trend WBC, bandemia
   .
   2. Hypotension: Likely [**3-5**] infection/sepsis. Pt received a total of 5l
   NS in the ED however still noted to have a SBP in the 90s. Pt was
   started on Levophed gtt in the ED. Hypotension may be a combination of
   hypovolemic state [**3-5**] poor PO intake, SIRS and Fentanyl/Versed. Will
   continue to give an additional NS bolus and titrate Levophed for a MAP
   >65. Give his concomittant tachycardia will like switch from Levophed
   to Phenylephrine if more pressor support is needed particularly as
   there will be less beta 1 receptor activation.
   --> repeat 1l NS bolus
   --> titrate Levophed for MAP >65, wean as tolerated
   --> Will consider switch from Levophed to Phenylephrine if he has
   persistent tachycardia and requirement of pressor support.
   .
   3. Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15, will
   transfuse 2u now. Will guaiaic stools x 3, start PPI [**Hospital1 **] though likely
   LGI bld. Patient endorses over the past few days BRBPR quantified as
   enough to fill a toilet [**Last Name (LF) 3860**], [**First Name3 (LF) 77**] son he has a history of BRBPR from
   ?hemorrhoids.? GI source versus malignancy related (met prostate ca).
   --> Transfuse 2 units PRBCs
   --> Repeat Hct, transfuse to goal of 21.
   --> PPI started, guaiaic stools x 3
   --> Consider GI consult in am.
   .
   4. Pneumonia: Chest x-ray in ED notable for RLL and RML PNA, pt noted
   to have volumous secretions from his trach as well as a fever (rectal
   temp 104.4), leukocytosis to 12.6 with bandemia. Prior to transfer to
   the floor he was noted to be hypoxic requiring intubation and
   ventilatory support. Hypotension has also been noted requiring
   Levophed. Will also start pt on an ARDS protocol for ventilation given
   the appearance of his CXR.
   --> As mentioned above Zosyn, Levofloxacin for double strep and staph
   coverage
   --> Will also start Vancomycin for MRSA coverage
   --> Sputum cultures, urinary legionella ordered.
   --> Follow bcx as above
   --> Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on PSV
   and tolerating well
   --> Morphine prn pleuritic pain
   .
   5. New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED at a
   rate within the 200s, diltiazem 10mg IV x 2 reduced HR to 150s, fluid
   administration further lowered to 130s. On arrival to the floor pt
   received an additional 10mg IV Diltiazem which reduced his HR to
   100-120s and received PO 12.5mg Metoprolol Tartrate x 1. Given his new
   Hct tachycardia is most likely compensatory, will hold beta blockers
   and assess response to transfusions.
   --> TTE ordered in the AM to assess new A. fib
   --> Will hold beta blockers until transfusion.
   --> Dilt as needed
   .
   6. Acute Kidney Injury: Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2, pt
   currently is in [**Last Name (un) **] with a Creatinine of 1.8. [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   given his current state of hypovolemia and anema.
   --> trend Cr following fluid administration
   --> Send urine lytes in am if no improvement
   .
   7. Anion Gap Acidosis: Pt has AG of 17, Anion Gap acidosis, given
   elevated lactic acid most likely lactic acidosis.
   - Continue to trend, no need for bicarb at this time
   .
   8. Hypotyhroidism: Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine
   .
   9. FEN/Lytes: NPO overnight, cardiac diet in am, replete lytes prn, IVF
   prn
   .
   10. Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, already on PPI. Hold on SQH given
   bleed/anemia
   .
   11. Code status: FULL CODE
   .

The patient's progress note indicates multiple medical complications. Here are the potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, temperature of >104, tachypnea, and white blood count with bandemia. Likely source is pneumonia. The patient received Levofloxacin, Cefepime, and Vancomycin in the ED.

2. Hypotension: The patient had persistent hypotension despite fluid resuscitation. Pressor support with Levophed was required. The hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, poor oral intake, SIRS, and the effects of Fentanyl/Versed. Additional NS bolus will be given and Levophed will be titrated for a MAP >65. If more pressor support is needed, Phenylephrine will be considered.

3. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, with a Hct of 23 on admission, which is likely artificially elevated due to hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15, and 2 units of PRBCs will be transfused now. PPI has been started, and guaiacol stools will be done x3. A GI consult may be considered.

4. Pneumonia: The patient has evidence of right lower and middle lobe pneumonia on chest x-ray, along with fever, leukocytosis, and band

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications. Here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The chest x-ray shows right lower lobe and right middle lobe pneumonia. The patient is already on antibiotics (Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin) for broad coverage, and sputum cultures are pending.

2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis with tachycardia, fever, and elevated white blood cell count with bandemia. It is likely that the source of SIRS is pneumonia. The lactate level initially noted to be high but improved following fluid administration.

3. Hypotension: The patient was initially hypotensive on transfer to the floor likely due to infection/sepsis. The patient received a total of 5 liters of normal saline in the emergency department but still had a systolic blood pressure in the 90s. The patient was started on Levophed in the emergency department, and after the placement of an arterial line, mean arterial pressure (MAP) has been >65, and Levophed has been discontinued.

4. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, with a hematocrit (Hct) of approximately 23% last year. On admission, the Hct was 24

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a medical history of metastatic prostate cancer, papillary thyroid cancer, and a smoking history. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to multifocal pneumonia, hematochezia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib w/ RVR), and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient's current condition indicates that he is critically ill, requiring mechanical ventilation and multiple lines for treatment.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to multifocal pneumonia. Complications associated with this condition may include worsening hypoxemia, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and barotrauma.

2. Hematochezia: Hematochezia refers to the passage of fresh blood per rectum. Complications related to this condition may include gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, and potential need for transfusions.

3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib w/ RVR): AFib w/ RVR is a cardiac arrhythmia characterized by rapid and irregular heartbeats. Complications associated with this condition may include tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy, stroke, and heart failure.

4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): ARF is a sudden decline in kidney function. Complications associated with this condition may include electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and

   Assessment and Plan
   # Sepsis: The patient continues Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive bandemia.
   Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1,
   however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was started on
   Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was started for
   broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage, Vancomycin for MRSA
   coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he became hypotensive and
   required pressure support again with Levophed as well as many IVF
   boluses.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, weaning levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   # Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarb of 13 and a pH on ABG of
   7.21.  His AG is 14.  Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary
   to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS he
   received yesterday.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - Will attempt to increase his tidal volume to induce a respiratory
   alkalosis to help compensate for his acidosis.
   - Continue to follow his pH on ABGs.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15 last night and
   23.8 this s/p 2units two days ago.  Yesterday am his Hct was again low
   at 21.8 so he was transfused another 2 units of PRBC (for a total of 4
   units).  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Will address goals of care at the family meeting today before
   deciding if to scope.
   - Q8H hct checks
   - Active type and screen
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on CMV
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr increased back to 1.8 (from
   1.4). Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   vs ATN given his recent hypotension. Pt still having poor urine output
   which has been unresponsive to IVF.
   - trend Cr
   - check urinary electrolytes
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. Will discuss with ENT
   whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather
   than the stoma.
   # Hypothyroidism:  TSH was normal at 3.0.
   -  Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine.

Summary:
The patient is an elderly Asian male who was admitted to the ICU for suspected community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). He presented with hypotension and was found to have a high fever, tachycardia, and hypoxia upon admission. The patient required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress.

During his stay in the ICU, the patient received several blood transfusions due to low hemoglobin levels. His heart function appears to be preserved with an ejection fraction greater than 55%. However, he does have mild aortic regurgitation and mild pulmonary hypertension. The patient's TSH level is within normal range.

The patient's vital signs have fluctuated throughout the day, with an increase in temperature and a decrease in blood pressure. His oxygen saturation has been maintained at around 98%. The patient is sedated with fentanyl and midazolam, and his sedation level needs to be adjusted to allow for bigger tidal volumes during ventilation.

The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube with continuous mandatory ventilation (CMV) and assist control mode. The tidal volume is set at 350 mL, respiratory rate at 18 breaths per minute, and PEEP at 12 cmH2O. FiO2 is currently set at 50%. The patient's ABG results show a slightly low pH, elevated PaCO2, and normal oxygen saturation.

Physical examination reveals that the patient appears tired but cooperative. His heart rhythm is irregular

   Assessment and Plan
   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   # Sepsis: The patient continues Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive bandemia.
   Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1,
   however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was started on
   Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was started for
   broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage, Vancomycin for MRSA
   coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he became hypotensive and
   required pressure support again with Levophed as well as many IVF
   boluses.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, weaning levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   # Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarb of 13 and a pH on ABG of
   7.21.  His AG is 14.  Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary
   to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS he
   received yesterday.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - Will attempt to increase his tidal volume to induce a respiratory
   alkalosis to help compensate for his acidosis.
   - Continue to follow his pH on ABGs.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15 last night and
   23.8 this s/p 2units two days ago.  Yesterday am his Hct was again low
   at 21.8 so he was transfused another 2 units of PRBC (for a total of 4
   units).  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Will address goals of care at the family meeting today before
   deciding if to scope.
   - Q8H hct checks
   - Active type and screen
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on CMV
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr increased back to 1.8 (from
   1.4). Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   vs ATN given his recent hypotension. Pt still having poor urine output
   which has been unresponsive to IVF.
   - trend Cr
   - check urinary electrolytes
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. Will discuss with ENT
   whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather
   than the stoma.
   # Hypothyroidism:  TSH was normal at 3.0.
   -  Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO while requiring pressors

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He is now septic and intubated.

The patient meets the criteria for sepsis with tachycardia, temperature of 102, tachypnea, and white blood count with bandemia. The likely source of SIRS is pneumonia. He has received broad-spectrum antibiotics including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin. He required pressor support with Levophed due to hypotension.

The patient also has metabolic acidosis with a bicarb of 13 and a pH of 7.21. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis is likely secondary to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of normal saline he received yesterday. He will be monitored closely for any changes in his condition.

The patient's hemoglobin levels have been fluctuating, ranging from 23.8 to 21.8. He has been transfused with a total of 4 units of packed red blood cells. Anemia is present, but no further clinical evidence of bleeding has been observed.

The patient's chest x-ray shows worsening pneumonia. He is on ARDS protocol, but his urinary Legionella antigen is negative. Cultures have been ordered, including

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old elderly Asian male who is intubated and admitted to the ICU. He has a history of anemia, hypothyroidism, and prostate cancer. The patient presented with sepsis, hypotension, anemia, pneumonia, and new-onset atrial fibrillation. His current condition includes acute kidney injury, agitation, and hypothyroidism. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, blood transfusions, and supportive care. The patient's medical team is considering a tracheostomy for long-term ventilatory support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever, tachypnea, and bandemia. The likely source of SIRS is pneumonia. The patient is already receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, but there is a risk of complications such as multi-organ dysfunction or septic shock.
2. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive despite fluid administration and vasopressor support. This may be due to a combination of hypovolemia, poor oral intake, SIRS, and medication effects. Close monitoring of blood pressure and continued use of vasopressors are necessary to maintain adequate blood pressure.

- He has a mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function, mild aortic regurgitation, mild pulmonary hypertension, and biatrial enlargement.
- The patient's condition is complicated by metabolic acidosis, sepsis, hypotension, anemia, pneumonia, new-onset atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, agitation, and a stoma.
- He requires mechanical ventilation and pressor support.
- The patient has a history of bowel irregularity and is currently on prophylactic antibiotics, including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill and experiencing several medical complications. Here are the potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Presumed sepsis: The patient has signs of infection, possibly from a respiratory infection source. This could lead to systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying smoking history and multifocal right-sided pneumonia have resulted in respiratory failure. This condition requires immediate attention, including intubation and mechanical ventilation.

3. Hematocchezia: The patient is experiencing bleeding, as indicated by the presence of blood in the urine. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the cause and treat it appropriately.

4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient developed atrial fibrillation likely due to hypovolemia. Rate control measures need to be implemented to manage this cardiac arrhythmia.

5. Acute renal failure: The patient's kidneys are not functioning properly, which may be related to hypovolemia. Close monitoring and careful fluid management are essential to prevent further deterioration of renal function.

6. Gastric stress ulcers: The patient is at risk for developing stress ulcers due to critical illness. Prophylactic treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) should be initiated to prevent this complication.

7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and critical illness increase the risk of developing DVT. Prophylactic measures such as wearing boots

 ANEMIA, ACUTE, SECONDARY TO BLOOD LOSS (HEMORRHAGE, BLEEDING)

   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   # Sepsis: The patient continues Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive bandemia.
   Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1,
   however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was started on
   Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was started for
   broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage, Vancomycin for MRSA
   coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he became hypotensive and
   required pressure support again with Levophed as well as many IVF
   boluses.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, weaning levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   # Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarb of 13 and a pH on ABG of
   7.21.  His AG is 14.  Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary
   to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS he
   received yesterday.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - Will attempt to increase his tidal volume to induce a respiratory
   alkalosis to help compensate for his acidosis.
   - Continue to follow his pH on ABGs.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15 last night and
   23.8 this s/p 2units two days ago.  Yesterday am his Hct was again low
   at 21.8 so he was transfused another 2 units of PRBC (for a total of 4
   units).  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Will address goals of care at the family meeting today before
   deciding if to scope.
   - Q8H hct checks
   - Active type and screen
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on CMV
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr increased back to 1.8 (from
   1.4). Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   vs ATN given his recent hypotension. Pt still having poor urine output
   which has been unresponsive to IVF.
   - trend Cr
   - check urinary electrolytes
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. Will discuss with ENT
   whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather
   than the stoma.
   # Hypothyroidism:  TSH was normal at 3.0.
   -  Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine.

Summary:
The patient is a 85-year-old male with a complex medical history including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He was found to meet SIRS criteria and was intubated due to sepsis. 

The patient has multiple medical complications including anemia, metabolic acidosis, pneumonia, acute kidney injury, and atrial fibrillation. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and requires pressor support with norepinephrine. 

He has a history of bleeding and required blood transfusions. His hemoglobin levels have been low, and he has received a total of 4 units of packed red blood cells. 

The patient's chest x-ray shows worsening pneumonia, and his urinary legionella antigen is negative. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin for coverage against MRSA. 

His metabolic acidosis is likely secondary to decreased ventilatory compensation and large-volume normal saline administration. 

The patient's acute kidney injury may be pre-renal or due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) given his recent hypotension and poor urine output. 

Other issues include a stoma, hypothyroidism, and the need for ongoing nutritional support and glycemic control.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill with several medical complications. The key findings and potential medical complications are as follows:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has bacterial pneumonia, which is evident from the diffuse alveolar infiltrate in the right hemithorax on the chest X-ray. This infection can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.

2. Hypotension: The patient has persistent hypotension despite vasopressor support. This could indicate a state of distributive shock, possibly secondary to septic shock due to the ongoing infection.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's rising creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure. This may be due to factors such as hypotension leading to decreased renal perfusion, or direct renal injury from the infection or toxins.

4. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has hyperchloremic non-gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to volume resuscitation with normal saline. This can occur in critically ill patients who receive large volumes of normal saline.

5. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss, likely from hemorrhage or bleeding. This can contribute to hypotension and tissue hypoperfusion.

6. Ventilatory Support: The patient requires mechanical ventilation with a combination of controlled mandatory ventilation (CMV) and assist-control ventilation (AC). This indicates severe respiratory compromise.

7. Fluid Balance: The patient has received a significant amount of fluids,

Summary:
The patient is an elderly male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He was found to have sepsis and was intubated. The patient has several medical complications including pneumonia, metabolic acidosis, anemia, acute kidney injury, and new-onset atrial fibrillation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is already septic and intubated, so there is a risk of further deterioration or development of multi-organ dysfunction syndrome.

2. Pneumonia: The patient has symptoms suggestive of pneumonia, and the chest x-ray confirms the presence of infiltrates. There is a risk of progression to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or failure.

3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis likely due to fluid resuscitation. Monitoring and correction of electrolyte imbalances are necessary to prevent further complications.

4. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and his current hemoglobin levels are low. Close monitoring and possible transfusion may be required to maintain adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's serum creatinine levels have increased, indicating possible acute kidney injury. Aggressive fluid resuscitation and careful monitoring of

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a medical history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He was found to have sepsis and intubated. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 38.3C (100.9F), heart rate 70 bpm, blood pressure 117/42 mmHg, respiratory rate 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on the ventilator. The patient's ABG results indicate a pH of 7.33, PaCO2 of 36 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 156. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, anemia, and acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient's prolonged intubation, there is a risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): Immobility and the presence of central venous lines increase the risk of DVT and subsequent PE.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient's critical illness and the use of corticosteroids may predispose him to stress ulcers.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory distress. The patient has been receiving various medications, including Vancomycin, Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), Fentanyl, and Midazolam. The patient's vital signs show a fever with a maximum temperature of 38.3C, heart rate within normal limits, low blood pressure, and normal respiratory rate. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is receiving supplemental oxygen. 

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the presence of a fever. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring indicates fluid balance with a total input of 2,837 mL and output of 738 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 2,099 mL. The patient's respiratory support shows a set tidal volume (Vt) of 400 mL, respiratory rate (RR) set at 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) at 12 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 50%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) values show a pH of 7.33, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 36 mmHg, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 156 mmHg, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 98%. 

The patient's physical examination reveals no assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, or neurologic status. Lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC), low hematocrit (Hct), normal platelet count (Plt), elevated creatinine (Cr), low total carbon dioxide (TCO2), normal glucose levels, and abnormal results for various other lab parameters including PT/PTT/INR, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T, differential, electrolytes, and lactate levels.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Anemia, acute secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding): The patient's low hematocrit levels suggest anemia, which may be due to blood loss.
2. Acidosis, metabolic: The patient's ABG results indicate a lower-than-normal pH level, indicating metabolic acidosis.
3. Hypotension (not in shock): The patient's blood pressure is low, which can be a concern for hypotension. However, the note specifies that it is not due to shock.
4. Pneumonia, bacterial, community-acquired (CAP): The patient's fever, abnormal lab results, and need for mechanical ventilation suggest a possible bacterial pneumonia.
5. ICU acquired complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and pressure ulcers should also be considered given the patient's prolonged stay in the ICU.

   started for broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage,
   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he
   became hypotensive and required pressure support again with Levophed as
   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough

   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - IVF bolus with LR and monitor lytes for hyperkalemia.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show

The patient has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics including levofloxacin, cefepime, and vancomycin. He required vasopressor support and has since been weaned off it. The patient also has metabolic acidosis, anemia, acute kidney injury, new-onset atrial fibrillation, and a stoma.

2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen if the current antibiotic therapy is ineffective or if there is an underlying resistant infection. This could result in further respiratory distress and potential need for mechanical ventilation.

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume (Vt) of 400 mL, respiratory rate (RR) set at 18, PEEP of 12 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%.

   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   #. Sepsis: On admission patient met SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have increased to trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive
   bandemia. Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted
   to be 6.1, however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was
   started on Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was
   started for broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage,
   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he
   became hypotensive and required pressure support again with Levophed as
   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, narrow spectrum if cultures turn
   positive
   - will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA screen negative
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, DFA for
   influenza pending.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, if pt requires vasopressor support will started
   levophed with vasopressin, will then attempt to wean off levophed and
   keep vasopressin for a 24 hour period. Will start pt on bolus of LR for
   IVF resuscitation.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   #. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap acidosis most
   likely related to his vast fluid resuscitation with normal saline.
   Following administration of 1L D5W with 3 amps of HCO3 pt
s CO2
   increased from 16 to 20. Will bolus IVF with LR and check PM lytes to
   monitor for hyperkalemia.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - IVF bolus with LR and monitor lytes for hyperkalemia.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Pt received 2units PRBC following a
   morning Hct of 15. Currently his Hct has been stable now at 30, will
   continue to monitor.  As pt has had not decrease in Hct over the past
   few days, will restart Heparin for prophylaxis.
   - Active type and screen
   - Continue to monitor Hct
   # Pneumonia: Culture data thus far negative to date. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA swab was
   negative

   - Will decrease FiO2 now and see how pt tolerates FiO2 of 40%. Will

   to trach mask with frequent suctioning of secretions.

s non-anion gap metabolic

Summary:
The patient is an elderly male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He was found to have sepsis and was intubated. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.1C (98.8F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 132/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on a tracheostomy tube with assisted mechanical ventilation. His general appearance is that of an elderly Asian male who is intubated via tracheostomy.

The patient has several medical complications. He has pneumonia, as indicated by his symptoms and the need for broad-spectrum antibiotics. He also has metabolic acidosis, possibly due to fluid resuscitation with normal saline. Additionally, he has acute kidney injury, with an elevated creatinine level and low urine output.

Other findings include anemia, with a history of anemia and a current hematocrit of 30%. The patient has a central line infection, as evidenced by the removal of his femoral central line. He also has a new onset of atrial fibrillation, which resolved spontaneously.

Summary:
The patient is a critically ill male with a diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia, sepsis, acute renal failure, anemia secondary to blood loss, and malnutrition. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been admitted to the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure of 137/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. He is receiving midazolam and fentanyl infusions for sedation and analgesia. Other medications include pantoprazole, heparin sodium, Synthroid, ferrous sulfate, levofloxacin, and Peridex.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.5 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL, platelet count of 150 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen level of 26.5 mg/dL, creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL, sodium level of 19 mEq/L, potassium level of 3.8 mEq/L, chloride level of 58 mg/dL, glucose level of 99 mg/dL, and a C-reactive protein level of 10.7 K/uL. The patient's imaging shows multifocal right-sided pneumonia.

The patient's current plan of care includes continuing vancomycin and piperacillin

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is critically ill and being treated in the ICU. They have been diagnosed with pneumonia, sepsis, acute renal failure, anemia due to blood loss, and malnutrition. The patient is on multiple medications including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), fentanyl, midazolam, pantoprazole, and heparin. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure of 137/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 2,812 mL, output of 910 mL, and a balance of 1,902 mL. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, elevated creatinine levels, and abnormal electrolyte levels. Imaging shows multifocal right pneumonia, and microbiology results are negative for bacterial growth. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, and their blood gases are within normal limits. The patient's nutritional status is being addressed with tube feeds and a nutrition consult. The patient is at risk for complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and further organ dysfunction.

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He was diagnosed with sepsis and intubated. The patient has several medical complications, including impaired skin integrity, anemia, metabolic acidosis, pneumonia, acute kidney injury, and atrial fibrillation.

The patient's impaired skin integrity is likely due to prolonged bedrest and immobility. Anemia is a pre-existing condition, but it may have worsened due to blood loss during his surgeries or as a result of sepsis. The metabolic acidosis is non-anion gap and is most likely related to fluid resuscitation with normal saline. Pneumonia is suspected based on the patient's symptoms and the presence of bandemia. Acute kidney injury is indicated by an increase in creatinine levels and low urine output, which could be due to either pre-renal or intrinsic renal damage. Atrial fibrillation was noted in the emergency department but resolved spontaneously.

Potential medical complications that can arise include further deterioration of the patient's renal function, worsening of pneumonia leading to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), development of pressure ulcers or decubitus ulcers due to impaired skin integrity, and potential infections at the site of the tracheostomy or other invasive lines.

Overall, the patient's condition requires close monitoring and aggressive management to address the various medical complications he is facing.

   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive

   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with

   septic and intubated.
   #. Sepsis: On admission patient met SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have increased to trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive
   bandemia. Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted
   to be 6.1, however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was
   started on Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was
   started for broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage,
   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he
   became hypotensive and required pressure support again with Levophed as
   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, narrow spectrum if cultures turn
   positive
   - will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA screen negative
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, DFA for
   influenza pending.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, if pt requires vasopressor support will started
   levophed with vasopressin, will then attempt to wean off levophed and
   keep vasopressin for a 24 hour period. Will start pt on bolus of LR for
   IVF resuscitation.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   #. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap acidosis most
   likely related to his vast fluid resuscitation with normal saline.
   Following administration of 1L D5W with 3 amps of HCO3 pt
s CO2
   increased from 16 to 20. Will bolus IVF with LR and check PM lytes to
   monitor for hyperkalemia.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - IVF bolus with LR and monitor lytes for hyperkalemia.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Pt received 2units PRBC following a
   morning Hct of 15. Currently his Hct has been stable now at 30, will
   continue to monitor.  As pt has had not decrease in Hct over the past
   few days, will restart Heparin for prophylaxis.
   - Active type and screen
   - Continue to monitor Hct
   # Pneumonia: Culture data thus far negative to date. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA swab was
   negative
   - Sputum cultures, DFA negative
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Will decrease FiO2 now and see how pt tolerates FiO2 of 40%. Will
   also aim to decrease PEEP from 12 to 8 with the goal of transitioning
   to trach mask with frequent suctioning of secretions.
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # Nutrition: Pt has been without nutrition, will consult nutrition
   regarding TF via NGT.

   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele

s Cr furthered increased to 3.0,
   baseline Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  Pt
s Creatinine with fluid
   resuscitation with urin output approx 50cc showed a decrease to 2.3,
   however overnight Creatinine increased back up to 3.0. Urine lytes have
   been ordered with a FENA suspicious for pre-renal. Will again
   administer IVF boluses with LR given the pt
s non-anion gap metabolic

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an elderly male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fever, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. The patient is currently intubated and in the ICU.

The patient's medical conditions include impaired skin integrity, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypotension (not in shock), and community-acquired pneumonia. His pneumonia has been improving with the use of Levofloxacin and Zosyn, but there is still a low threshold to restart Vancomycin if the patient shows signs of deterioration.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, and normal platelet count. His electrolyte levels are within normal range except for a slightly low calcium level. Other lab results indicate acute kidney injury, but the creatinine level is trending down.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing with antibiotics, monitoring for any signs of deterioration or worsening clinical exam, and restarting Vancomycin if necessary. The patient's sedation will be weaned down, and he will be transitioned to a tracheostomy mask for possible rehabilitation. A percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement is scheduled today due to the patient's inability to take oral feeds. The patient's albumin level is low

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, SCC of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the ED with symptoms of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He is currently septic and intubated. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and pressure support. His pneumonia is showing improvement, and he has been able to tolerate less support from the ventilator. He has been on Levofloxacin and Zosyn for coverage, and Vancomycin was discontinued as MRSA swabs were negative. The patient's leukocytosis has increased off of Vancomycin.

The patient's anemia is being monitored, and he received 2 units of PRBC due to a morning Hct of 15. His Hct is now stable at 30. Sedation is being weaned, and the goal is to transition the patient to a tracheostomy mask and possible rehab. The patient is undergoing PEG placement today, and his albumin level is low at 1.9.

The patient's Cr is trending down to 2.4, and the cause is pre-renal. The patient is euvolemic now, and there is a preference for slightly dry volume status given the goal of weaning to a tracheostomy mask.

1. Impaired skin integrity: The

   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   #. Sepsis: On admission patient met SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have increased to trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive
   bandemia. Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted
   to be 6.1, however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was
   started on Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was
   started for broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage,
   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he
   became hypotensive and required pressure support again with Levophed as
   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, narrow spectrum if cultures turn
   positive
   - will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA screen negative
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, DFA for
   influenza pending.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, if pt requires vasopressor support will started
   levophed with vasopressin, will then attempt to wean off levophed and
   keep vasopressin for a 24 hour period. Will start pt on bolus of LR for
   IVF resuscitation.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   #. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap acidosis most
   likely related to his vast fluid resuscitation with normal saline.
   Following administration of 1L D5W with 3 amps of HCO3 pt
s CO2
   increased from 16 to 20. Will bolus IVF with LR and check PM lytes to
   monitor for hyperkalemia.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - IVF bolus with LR and monitor lytes for hyperkalemia.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Pt received 2units PRBC following a
   morning Hct of 15. Currently his Hct has been stable now at 30, will
   continue to monitor.  As pt has had not decrease in Hct over the past
   few days, will restart Heparin for prophylaxis.
   - Active type and screen
   - Continue to monitor Hct
   # Pneumonia: Culture data thus far negative to date. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA swab was
   negative
   - Sputum cultures, DFA negative
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Will decrease FiO2 now and see how pt tolerates FiO2 of 40%. Will
   also aim to decrease PEEP from 12 to 8 with the goal of transitioning
   to trach mask with frequent suctioning of secretions.
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # Nutrition: Pt has been without nutrition, will consult nutrition
   regarding TF via NGT.
   - Nutrition consult for TF
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr furthered increased to 3.0,
   baseline Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  Pt
s Creatinine with fluid
   resuscitation with urin output approx 50cc showed a decrease to 2.3,
   however overnight Creatinine increased back up to 3.0. Urine lytes have
   been ordered with a FENA suspicious for pre-renal. Will again
   administer IVF boluses with LR given the pt
s non-anion gap metabolic
   acidosis from NS fluid resuscitation for a goal of UOP >50cc/hr. Given
   low urine output [**Last Name (un) **] most likely [**3-5**] ATN versus pre-renal. Will
   continue to give fluid today and monitor UOP.
   - trend Cr
   -LR bolus
   # Nutrition: Pt currently has tube feeds via NG tube. Discussed with
   family who states that pt would want all measures of support. Pt
   unlikely to be taking PO [**3-5**] current clinical state. Will consult GI
   for a PEG placement for nutrition, will also obtain Albumin level.
   -Albumin level ordered
   -GI consult for PEG placement
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. ENT consulted yesterday for
   trach placement however were unable to place as another pt needed a
   STAT airway.
   - ENT placed trach size 7.0 yesterday

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a medical history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, metastatic prostate cancer, and previous blood loss. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fever, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. The patient was diagnosed with sepsis and intubated.

Current Assessment and Plan:

1. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has areas of impaired skin integrity, likely due to immobility and pressure from medical devices.
2. Anemia, acute secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding): The patient has a history of anemia, and his hematocrit levels indicate acute blood loss.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, possibly related to fluid resuscitation with normal saline.
4. Hypotension (not in shock): The patient experienced hypotension and required vasopressor support.
5. Pneumonia, bacterial, community-acquired (CAP): The patient has signs of pneumonia, and treatment has been initiated with antibiotics.
6. New onset atrial fibrillation: The patient was in atrial fibrillation but resolved once in the ICU.
7. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels indicate acute kidney injury, which may be pre-renal or due to acute tubular necrosis.
8. Malnutrition: The patient

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill and has several medical complications. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). This condition can worsen if not properly treated with antibiotics.

2. Sepsis: The patient is currently resolving from sepsis, which is a life-threatening response to infection. Close monitoring is necessary to prevent recurrence.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is likely experiencing acute renal failure due to factors such as distributive/hypovolemic shock and acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Fluid management and monitoring urine output are crucial in managing this condition.

4. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss. Close monitoring of hemoglobin levels and blood products administration are required to maintain stable hemoglobin levels.

5. Large Bowel Obstruction: The patient previously had a large bowel obstruction, which has since resolved. Monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications related to bowel function is important.

6. Malnutrition: The patient requires nutritional support due to malnutrition. A nutrition consult has been ordered, and the patient is scheduled for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement.

7. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and there is a risk of developing VAP. Prophylactic measures should be taken to minimize this risk.

8. Deep

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a complex medical history including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fever, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. The patient was diagnosed with sepsis and intubated. 

The patient has been experiencing hypertension, alteration in nutrition, impaired skin integrity, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypotension, and community-acquired pneumonia. The pneumonia was initially treated with Levofloxacin and Zosyn, and Vancomycin was discontinued after negative MRSA swabs. 

The patient's leukocytosis improved after discontinuing Vancomycin, and his clinical condition has shown improvement. He is currently on pressure support 15/10 and is expected to undergo percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement today. 

The patient's blood work shows anemia, with a hematocrit (Hct) level of 30, which is being monitored. His kidney function is improving, with a decreasing creatinine level. 

The patient's sedation will be weaned down, transitioning from propofol and fentanyl to only fentanyl boluses. He is also expected to have a PEG tube placed for nutrition. 

The patient's family has been informed, and the primary person of contact is

The patient has been diagnosed with severe pneumonia, which is showing improvement. He is currently receiving antibiotics (Levofloxacin and Zosyn) and his clinical condition appears to be better.

The patient also has hypertension, altered nutrition, impaired skin integrity, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypotension, and community-acquired pneumonia. His leukocytosis has increased after stopping Vancomycin, but he does not seem to be clinically worse.

The patient's Hct level was artificially elevated due to hypovolemia/hemoconcentration, and he received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC). His Hct level has stabilized at 30, and further monitoring is recommended.

The patient is still sedated on propofol and fentanyl, with the goal of transitioning him to a tracheostomy mask and possible rehabilitation. The plan is to wean down sedation and use only fentanyl boluses.

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a medical history of papillary thyroid carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, metastatic prostate cancer, and previous surgeries including thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation, total laryngectomy with modified radical neck dissection, and creation of a stoma. He presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fever, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough, and was found to be septic and intubated. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia, acute anemia due to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypotension, hypertension, altered nutrition, impaired skin integrity, and acute kidney injury. He has been placed on various medications including levofloxacin and zosyn for pneumonia treatment, and has undergone a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient is currently being treated for community-acquired pneumonia with levofloxacin and zosyn. Monitoring for any worsening clinical exam, desaturation, or positive sputum/blood cultures is important to consider restarting vancomycin if necessary.
2. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and his current hemoglobin level is stable at 30 after receiving 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs). Continued monitoring of hemoglobin levels is necessary.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He is currently septic and intubated.

The patient underwent a PEG tube placement yesterday and experienced hypertension that required treatment with metoprolol and hydralazine. Propofol was discontinued, and his sedation is being weaned off.

His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C (97.4F), heart rate of 62 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 128/55 mmHg to 225/110 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation above 98%. He is on CPAP/PSV ventilation with a tidal volume set at 400 mL.

The patient's physical examination reveals a slightly distended abdomen, normoactive bowel sounds, no facial grimacing upon palpation, and 3+ edema in both upper extremities. Neurological examination shows that the patient can open his eyes, communicate with his son, and flex his toes on command.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count within normal range, hemoglobin level of 9.3 g/dL, blood urea nitrogen level of 41 mg/dL, creat

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease, diabetes, and hypertension. He was admitted to the ICU with community-acquired pneumonia, sepsis, acute renal failure, anemia secondary to blood loss, and malnutrition. The patient underwent percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement yesterday. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and receiving multiple medications including antibiotics, antifungals, sedatives, and analgesics. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure of 161/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. Physical examination reveals crackles in the chest, edema in both lower extremities, and scrotal edema. The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, elevated creatinine, low albumin, and electrolyte imbalances. Imaging and microbiology results are unremarkable. The patient's conditions include pneumonia, sepsis, acute renal failure, anemia, and malnutrition. The plan is to continue weaning off sedation, minimize ventilator support, start tube feeds, and optimize glycemic control.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is resolving slowly with evidence of necrosis on chest X-ray. There is a risk of worsening or developing complications such as abscess formation

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an elderly male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. He was found to be septic and intubated. The patient has severe pneumonia showing improvement, leukocytosis that is now trending down, and has responded well to antibiotics. He is being weaned off sedation and is interactive. The patient has anemia secondary to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypertension, impaired skin integrity, and hypernatremia. He is currently receiving IV fluids, antibiotics, and has a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placed for nutrition. 

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Pneumonia: Despite improvement, there is still a risk of worsening or recurrence of pneumonia due to the patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory support.
2. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss, which may require further transfusion support or intervention.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis, which can lead to organ dysfunction if not corrected.
4. Hypertension: The patient has chronic hypertension, which needs to be managed and monitored closely.
5. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, particularly in the scrotal area, which increases the risk

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He underwent thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation, total laryngectomy with modified radical neck dissection, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient is currently requiring ventilatory support in the ICU.

24-hour events:
1. Left upper extremity (LUE) showed complete occlusive thrombus surrounding the left percutaneous central catheter (PICC) line in the left brachial and axillary veins. A second thrombus was noted in another brachial vein. The PICC line was removed, and a right femoral line was placed instead. The patient also had right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain, and a computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a large rectus hematoma measuring 12 cm craniocaudal x 6.5 cm transverse x 2.8 cm anterior-posterior. s leukocytosis

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an elderly male with a complex medical history including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, metastatic prostate cancer, and previous sepsis. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU and requires ventilatory support.

The patient's recent events include the development of occlusive thrombus surrounding the left PICC line in the left brachial and axillary veins, as well as a thrombus within a second left brachial vein. The PICC line was removed, and the patient is now on anticoagulation therapy.

Additionally, the patient has a large rectus hematoma, which was discovered after experiencing right lower quadrant pain. New lesions within the liver are suspicious for metastasis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 68 bpm, blood pressure of 147/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on the ventilator.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16.4 K/uL, elevated hemoglobin level of 8.9 g/dL, elevated creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL, and low albumin level of 1.9 g/dL. The patient's electrolytes are within normal range, except for slightly elevated sodium level of 146 mEq/L

The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for ventilatory support. 1. Pneumonia: The patient has severe pneumonia that is improving, but still requires continued antibiotic coverage with Levofloxacin and Zosyn for a total of 10 days. Close monitoring of the patient's pulmonary examination and radiographical data is necessary.
2. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and his Hct has been stable at 30 following a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC). Continuous monitoring of the patient's Hct is recommended.
3. Sedation: The goal is to wean the patient off Fentanyl so that he can be awake enough to transition to a tracheostomy mask and possibly rehabilitation. Transitioning from a Fentanyl drip to a patch will be attempted.
4. Nutrition: The patient has a PEG tube placed yesterday, and enteral feeding will be restarted today as the patient is 24

   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history

   undergoing PEG tube placement. He is currently on Levofloxacin and
   Zosyn for coverage. Interestingly, pt
s leukocytosis increased
   intermittently but now is starting to trend back down. He clinically
   though does appear to be better. If pt does appear to decompensate or
   starts to desaturate, has worsening clinical exam or clinical data will

s free water deficit is 1.7L will add free H20

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an elderly male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He presented to the emergency department with fevers, chills, fatigue, poor oral intake, and non-productive cough. The patient is currently septic and intubated.

Medical Complications:

1. Occlusive thrombus: The patient has an occlusive thrombus surrounding the left percutaneous central catheter (PICC) line in the left brachial and axillary veins. There is also a thrombus in a second left brachial vein. This could lead to complications such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), or peripheral thrombophlebitis.

2. Rectus hematoma: The patient has a large rectus hematoma measuring 12 cm craniocaudal x 6.5 cm transverse x 2.8 cm anterior-posterior. This could potentially cause pain, bleeding, or pressure effects on surrounding structures.

3. Liver lesions: The patient has new lesions within the liver that are suspicious for metastasis. This indicates the progression of his prostate cancer and may require further evaluation and treatment.

4. Hypernatremia: The patient is slightly hypernatremic with a sodium level of 146. This could be due to poor intake and dehydration. It needs to be corrected to prevent complications such as

He has undergone several surgeries and treatments such as thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation, total laryngectomy with modified radical neck dissection, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) requiring ventilatory support.

The patient's recent medical complications include pneumonia, upper extremity thrombus, rectus sheath hematoma, new liver masses, anemia, hypernatremia, acute kidney injury, and scrotal edema. His current vital signs are within normal limits, with a blood pressure of 144/56 mmHg, heart rate of 67 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 95%, and temperature of 36.8C.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16.4 thousand cells per microliter, slightly low hemoglobin level of 8.4 g/dL, elevated creatinine level of 2.6 mg/dL, and abnormal liver function tests including an alkaline phosphatase level of 100 U/L and total bilirubin level of 1.9 mg/dL.

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He has undergone a thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation, total laryngectomy with modified radical neck dissection, and placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG). The patient is currently on ventilatory support in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient has severe pneumonia that is improving. He is being treated with Levofloxacin and Zosyn. His leukocytosis is increasing intermittently but trending back down. Sputum cultures, blood cultures, and DFA are negative.
2. Upper extremity thrombus: The patient has an occlusive thrombus around his PICC line. Anticoagulation was not started due to his recent rectus hematoma and bleeding around his central line site.
3. Rectus sheath hematoma: The patient likely developed a secondary hematoma due to subcutaneous heparin shots. Subcutaneous heparin has been discontinued, and Hct will be followed daily. Pneumoboots will be used for prophylaxis.
4. New liver masses seen on CT: The patient has a history of three malignancies and widespread bony metastatic disease from prostate cancer. New masses seen on CT likely represent metastases. A family meeting will be held to reassess

   continues to manifest anasarca and tenderness in RLQ.
   Exam notable for Tm of 98.2 BP of 144/56 HR of 65 RR of 18 with sat on

   he is at high risk for bleeding and anticoagulation will be withheld
   until PICC/ Midline placed in RUE.
   I have had a long discussion today ( nearly 30 minutes) with the aid of
   translator with his son to discuss ongoing medical issues and recent
   CT/ USG findings. I have told him that we will continue full supportive
   care short of CPR in the event of a septic hemodynamic decline, as that
   would be futile therapy. The orders will reflect that ( i.e CPR not
   indicated).
   I am hopeful that we will be able to transition off PEEP and current
   CPAP settings with diuresis if he does not have another infectious
   complication. He remains frail with progressive metastatic disease and
   family is aware of this too

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He has undergone multiple surgeries and treatments, including a thyroidectomy, radioactive iodine ablation, total laryngectomy with modified radical neck dissection, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure and requires ventilatory support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient has severe pneumonia that is improving, but there is a risk of recurrence or worsening of the infection.
2. Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has developed an occlusive thrombus around his PICC line, indicating a potential risk for DVT. Anticoagulation has been withheld due to the patient's recent rectus hematoma and bleeding around his central line site.
3. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and his hematocrit (Hct) levels have been decreasing. Close monitoring and potential transfusion may be necessary.
4. Sedation: The patient is heavily sedated and requires weaning off fentanyl to facilitate transition to tracheostomy mask and possible rehabilitation.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient was previously hypernatremic, but has been normalized with free water boluses. Daily electrolyte monitoring is recommended.
6. Acute Kidney

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly male with multiple comorbidities including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, metastatic prostate cancer, resolved sepsis, and pneumonia. He is currently intubated and requires ventilatory support.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 153/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His temperature is within normal range.

The patient has a history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT), acute respiratory failure, hypertension, alteration in nutrition, impaired skin integrity, anemia secondary to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypotension, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. He also has new liver masses seen on CT scan, which are likely representing metastases from his known malignancies.

The patient's lab results show leukocytosis, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal liver function tests. His hemoglobin (Hct) levels have been fluctuating, with a recent decrease to 23% that improved to 29% after receiving a blood transfusion. There is concern for possible gastrointestinal bleeding or retroperitoneal bleed, but further imaging may be required to confirm.

The patient's sedation plan involves using a Fentanyl patch and weaning off the gtt form. If agitation occurs, Haldol PRN may be considered. The

He has undergone thyroidectomy with radioactive iodine ablation, total laryngectomy with modified radical neck dissection, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement.

2. The patient is currently intubated and requires ventilatory support due to SCC of the larynx. He has completed a 10-day course of Levofloxacin and Zosyn for pneumonia, and his clinical examination is improving.

3. The patient has pleural effusions, and his 24-hour fluid output goal is set at -500 to -1 L to improve the effusions. He is being diuresed with intravenous Lasix as needed.

4. The patient's leukocytosis is improving, and his last sputum culture showed no growth.

5. The patient had an occlusive thrombus around his peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) and has undergone PICC removal. Anticoagulation was not initiated due to recent rectus hematoma and bleeding around his central line site. A request is in for a right midline placement, and the central line will be disconnected once the midline is placed.

s clinical examination is
   improving. CPAP 15/8, pt still has pleural effusions. As the patient is

s leukocytosis is currently improving will continue to trend.

   using prn lasix as needed.  Can also further decrease the free water
   flushes as his Na has been stable (had been previously increased due to

   central line site.
   - Request is in for Rt midline placement

s Hct decreased two days ago to 23 with an increase to 29

   so it is highly unlikely given the Hct drop that the pt has a GI bld
   that explains it. Given his current BPS a retroperitoneal bleed is also

s Hct may be a

 27.3)

s kidney function improving as he is recovering from

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has completed a 10-day course of antibiotics for pneumonia, but the clinical examination is improving. It is important to monitor for any signs of worsening respiratory symptoms or positive culture results.

2. Pleural effusions: The patient still has pleural effusions despite being on CPAP support. This could indicate ongoing fluid accumulation in the lungs and should be addressed with appropriate interventions.

3. Thrombus in PICC line: The patient was found to have an occlusive thrombus around his PICC line, which was subsequently removed. Anticoagulation therapy should be considered to prevent further clot formation.

4. Anemia: The patient's Hct levels have been fluctuating, with a recent decrease to 23 and an increase to 29 following a blood transfusion. This suggests ongoing blood loss or dilutional anemia. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause, such as GI bleeding or retroperitoneal bleed.

5. New liver masses: The patient has new liver masses seen on CT, which are likely representing metastases from his known malignancies. This indicates progression of disease and potential complications related to liver function.

6. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels have improved from an admission level of 3.0 to 1.5. It is crucial to continue monitoring kidney function and adjust fluid management
